t: Proverbs 6
My*p son, if thou be surety for thy friend, if thou hast stricken thy hand with a stranger,
Thou*p art snared with the words of thy mouth, thou art taken with the words of thy mouth.
Do*p this now, my son, and deliver thyself, when thou art come into the hand of thy friend; go, humble thyself, and make sure thy friend.
Give*p not sleep to thine eyes, nor slumber to thine eyelids.
Deliver*p thyself as a roe from the hand of the hunter, and as a bird from the hand of the fowler.
Go*p to the ant, thou sluggard; consider her ways, and be wise:
Which*p having no guide, overseer, or ruler,
Provideth*p her meat in the summer, and gathereth her food in the harvest.
How*p long wilt thou sleep, O sluggard? when wilt thou arise out of thy sleep?
Yet*p a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to sleep:
So*p shall thy poverty come as one that travelleth, and thy want as an armed man.
A*p naughty person, a wicked man, walketh with a froward mouth.
He*p winketh with his eyes, he speaketh with his feet, he teacheth with his fingers;
Frowardness*p is in his heart, he deviseth mischief continually; he soweth discord.
Therefore*p shall his calamity come suddenly; suddenly shall he be broken without remedy.
These*p six things doth the Lord*s hate: yea, seven are an abomination unto him:
A*p proud look, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood,
An*p heart that deviseth wicked imaginations, feet that be swift in running to mischief,
A*p false witness that speaketh lies, and he that soweth discord among brethren.
My*p son, keep thy father's commandment, and forsake not the law of thy mother:
Bind*p them continually upon thine heart, and tie them about thy neck.
When*p thou goest, it shall lead thee; when thou sleepest, it shall keep thee; and when thou awakest, it shall talk with thee.
For*p the commandment is a lamp; and the law is light; and reproofs of instruction are the way of life:
To*p keep thee from the evil woman, from the flattery of the tongue of a strange woman.
Lust*p not after her beauty in thine heart; neither let her take thee with her eyelids.
For*p by means of a whorish woman a man is brought to a piece of bread: and the adulteress will hunt for the precious life.
Can*p a man take fire in his bosom, and his clothes not be burned?
Can*p one go upon hot coals, and his feet not be burned?
So*p he that goeth in to his neighbour's wife; whosoever toucheth her shall not be innocent.
Men*p do not despise a thief, if he steal to satisfy his soul when he is hungry;
But*p if he be found, he shall restore sevenfold; he shall give all the substance of his house.
But*p whoso committeth adultery with a woman lacketh understanding: he that doeth it destroyeth his own soul.
A*p wound and dishonour shall he get; and his reproach shall not be wiped away.
For*p jealousy is the rage of a man: therefore he will not spare in the day of vengeance.
He*p will not regard any ransom; neither will he rest content, though thou givest many gifts.
